messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 52 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Minimum Weight Euclidean (1+"ERROR \eps")-SpannersA preliminary version of this paper appears in the Proceedings of the 48th International Workshop on Graph-Theoretic Concepts in Computer Science (WG), LNCS, Springer, 2022.

Paper Abstract: Abstract Given a set S𝑆S of n𝑛n points in the plane and a parameter ε>0𝜀0\varepsilon>0, a Euclidean (1+ε)1𝜀(1+\varepsilon)-spanner is a geometric graph G=(S,E)𝐺𝑆𝐸G=(S,E) that contains, for all p,q∈S𝑝𝑞𝑆p,q\in S, a p​q𝑝𝑞pq-path of weight at most (1+ε)​‖p​q‖1𝜀norm𝑝𝑞(1+\varepsilon)\|pq\|. We show that the minimum weight of a Euclidean (1+ε)1𝜀(1+\varepsilon)-spanner for n𝑛n points in the unit square [0,1]2superscript012[0,1]^{2} is O​(ε−3/2​n)𝑂superscript𝜀32𝑛O(\varepsilon^{-3/2}\,\sqrt{n}), and this bound is the best possible. The upper bound is based on a new spanner algorithm in the plane. It improves upon the baseline O​(ε−2​n)𝑂superscript𝜀2𝑛O(\varepsilon^{-2}\sqrt{n}), obtained by combining a tight bound for the weight of a Euclidean minimum spanning tree (MST) on n𝑛n points in [0,1]2superscript012[0,1]^{2}, and a tight bound for the lightness of Euclidean (1+ε)1𝜀(1+\varepsilon)-spanners, which is the ratio of the spanner weight to the weight of the MST. Our result generalizes to Euclidean d𝑑d-space for every constant dimension d∈ℕ𝑑ℕd\in\mathbb{N}: The minimum weight of a Euclidean (1+ε)1𝜀(1+\varepsilon)-spanner for n𝑛n points in the unit cube [0,1]dsuperscript01𝑑[0,1]^{d} is Od​(ε(1−d2)/d​n(d−1)/d)subscript𝑂𝑑superscript𝜀1superscript𝑑2𝑑superscript𝑛𝑑1𝑑O_{d}(\varepsilon^{(1-d^{2})/d}n^{(d-1)/d}), and this bound is the best possible. For the n×n𝑛𝑛n\times n section of the integer lattice in the plane, we show that the minimum weight of a Euclidean (1+ε)1𝜀(1+\varepsilon)-spanner is between Ω​(ε−3/4⋅n2)Ω⋅superscript𝜀34superscript𝑛2\Omega(\varepsilon^{-3/4}\cdot n^{2}) and O​(ε−1​log⁡(ε−1)⋅n2)𝑂⋅superscript𝜀1superscript𝜀1superscript𝑛2O(\varepsilon^{-1}\log(\varepsilon^{-1})\cdot n^{2}). These bounds become Ω​(ε−3/4⋅n)Ω⋅superscript𝜀34𝑛\Omega(\varepsilon^{-3/4}\cdot\sqrt{n}) and O​(ε−1​log⁡(ε−1)⋅n)𝑂⋅superscript𝜀1superscript𝜀1𝑛O(\varepsilon^{-1}\log(\varepsilon^{-1})\cdot\sqrt{n}) when scaled to a grid of n𝑛n points in the unit square. In particular, this shows that the integer grid is not an extremal configuration for minimum weight Euclidean (1+ε)1𝜀(1+\varepsilon)-spanners. Keywords: Euclidean spanner, minimum weight, integer lattice, Yao-graph

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 52 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 52"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "δ-Greedy t-spanner",
        "Range searching",
        "Lower bound for sparse Euclidean spanners",
        "Theta-3 is connected",
        "On the spanning and routing ratios of the directed Θ6-graph",
        "On sparse spanners of weighted graphs",
        "Efficient construction of a bounded-degree spanner with low weight",
        "New and improved spanning ratios for Yao graphs",
        "Euclidean steiner spanners: Light and sparse",
        "Greedy spanners are optimal in doubling metrics",
        "Towards tight bounds on theta-graphs: More is not always better",
        "Improved bounds on the spanning ratio of the theta-5-graph",
        "A spanner for the day after",
        "On locality-sensitive orderings and their applications",
        "An optimal algorithm for constructing oriented Voronoi diagrams and geographic neighborhood graphs",
        "Approximation algorithms for shortest path motion planning",
        "Optimally sparse spanners in 3-dimensional Euclidean space",
        "A fast algorithm for constructing sparse euclidean spanners",
        "A new way to weigh malnourished Euclidean graphs",
        "Low-light trees, and tight lower bounds for Euclidean spanners",
        "Discrépance des suites de Farey",
        "Lattice spanners of low degree",
        "Optimal Euclidean spanners: Really short, thin, and lanky",
        "The shortest path and the shortest road through n points",
        "The greedy spanner is existentially optimal",
        "Les suites de Farey et les problèmes des nombres premiers",
        "Efficient Yao graph construction",
        "A note on optimal degree-three spanners of the square lattice",
        "Deformable spanners and applications",
        "A light metric spanner",
        "Dilation and detours in geometric networks",
        "Fast greedy algorithms for constructing sparse geometric spanners",
        "Geometric Approximation Algorithms, volume 173 of Mathematics Surveys and Monographs",
        "Farey series and a theorem of Minkowski",
        "Approximation of real numbers by rationals: Some metric theorems",
        "Approximating the complete Euclidean graph",
        "Classes of graphs which approximate the complete Euclidean graph",
        "Bemerkungen zu der vorstehenden Abhandlung von Herrn Franel",
        "Light Euclidean spanners with Steiner points",
        "Truly optimal Euclidean spanners",
        "A unified framework for light spanners",
        "The discrepancy of Farey series",
        "Improved algorithms for constructing fault-tolerant spanners",
        "Proximity algorithms",
        "Geometric Spanner Networks",
        "Approximating geometrical graphs via ”spanners” and ”banyans”",
        "Fully dynamic geometric spanners",
        "Approximating the d-dimensional complete Euclidean graph",
        "Balancing degree, diameter, and weight in euclidean spanners",
        "Worst-case growth rates of some classical problems of combinatorial optimization",
        "The travelling salesman problem and minimum matching in the unit square",
        "On constructing minimum spanning trees in k-dimensional spaces and related problems"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 52 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Minimum Weight Euclidean (1+\"ERROR \\eps\")-SpannersA preliminary version of this paper appears in the Proceedings of the 48th International Workshop on Graph-Theoretic Concepts in Computer Science (WG), LNCS, Springer, 2022., providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
